ok, and would you say, that a sphere provides a better starting point for e=
volving bilateral symmetric organisms than other starting points? I suppose=
 that this should be the case. However, it could be that the objective sear=
ch favors occasionally deceptive stepping stones (with regard to symmetrica=
l objects).

On the other hand, we have to admit that this is just a proper=
ty that would be nice to see in the evolutionary search. We don't know, whe=
ther organisms with a high degree of symmetry would really outperform the o=
rganisms that you found.

Best,
Martin


--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff =
Clune <jclune@...> wrote:
>
> Hi Martin,
> 
> The CPPNs we used have a dist=
ance from center output. So they are easily able to make spheres in the cen=
ter of the bounding box (by just using that input and ignoring x, y, and z)=
. We often saw spherical "rollers" that dropped and expanded part of their =
sphere to push them away from the origin. So there is nothing in principle =
that prevented them from elaborating on a symmetrical, spherical starting p=
oint.  
> 
> 
> Best regards,
> Jeff Clune
> 
> Assistant Professor
> Compu=
ter Science
> University of Wyoming
> jeffclune@...
> jeffclune.com
> 
> On=
 Apr 15, 2013, at 6:21 AM, martin_pyka <martin.pyka@...> wrote:
> 
> > > > =
That certainly makes sense. It raises the question of how bilateral symmetr=
y arose in biological organisms.
> > 
> > I have no link to literature or a=
ny kind of evidence, but with regard to this paper I was wondering what kin=
d of creatures would emerge if you would start with an organism that has sp=
herical symmetry (as far as you can represent spherical symmetry with voxel=
s ;)) encoded through a CPPN. This ancestor organism would be something lik=
e a unicellular organism in nature. Starting with a CPPN of such an organis=
m would mean that radial and bilateral symmetry is in actual fact a departu=
re from spherical symmetry. And I suspect that from this starting position =
bilateral symmetry should be easier to reach (and it is maybe biologically =
more plausible!?).
> > 
> > @Jeff: can you try that for us? :-)
> > 
> > Fr=
om this perspective, complexification (or diversification) would mean break=
ing the symmetry rather than approaching it, which seems to me more natural=
. But as I said, I am not familiar with the literature in this area.
> > 
>=
 > Best,
> > Martin
> > 
> >
>
